;世界再次被最新的技术热潮席卷。人工智能 (AI) 被视为伟大的转折点，许多人认为它将带来一个要么丰富，要么毁灭的新时代。

;

;随着道德恐慌降临，这种歇斯底里席卷了教育界。机构； ChatGPT 之于写作和研究就像计算器之于算术一样。同样，乐观的评论家宣称人工智能是学习个性化的灵丹妙药，可以在世界范围内创造公平的竞争环境。

;

;人工智能对教育的真正影响还有待观察。作为孟加拉国创新计划 a2i 的顾问，我不禁有一种似曾相识的感觉。

;

;在人工智能狂热之前，区块链被宣传为巨大的颠覆性力量，它将重新分配财富并在网上带来信任和所有权。在教育领域，区块链被视为解决从认证认证到考试验证等诸多弊病的灵丹妙药。然而，区块链对教育的影响虽然真实，但却是有限的。

;

;我们不应该把注意力集中在最新的炒作技术上，而应该将注意力集中在简单、具有成本效益的实施上，这些实施可以真正改变教育的现状。我们对待教育的方式。

;

;在孟加拉国，我们有一种“节俭创新”的理念，这需要对我们的教育系统进行低成本的改变，从而取得不成比例的成果。疫情期间就是一个例子。尽管学校关闭了 18 个月，但课程没有停止超过两周。

;

;学校一关闭，政府就开始将免费的议会电视频道变成远程频道。学习频道。结果令人震惊。

;

;在 Covid-19 之前，孟加拉国有一个一刀切的学习计划。在线教育意味着每个学生的学习都变得个性化。环境而非设计引发了向个性化学习的转变。这为我们今天在孟加拉国实现“智能学习”方法的愿景提供了信息。

;

;孟加拉国在调整教育公共服务方面的速度比许多发达国家快得多。原因很简单。与其他人口众多的新兴经济体一样，在孟加拉国，风险要高得多。有了受过良好教育、年轻且具备数字化能力的劳动力队伍，一个国家就可以跨越发展阶段。但受教育程度低且无所事事的年轻人可能会破坏一个国家的稳定。

;

;孟加拉国有超过 4500 万年龄在 15 至 29 岁的年轻人。根据其到 2041 年成为数字化国家的愿景，建立了坚实的基础今天，面向未来的技能将被证明至关重要。毫不奇怪，如今孟加拉国十分之九的求职者需要具备数字技能。

;

;当然，孟加拉国向更加混合的学习方法的转变并不是从大流行开始的。向数字化学习方法迈进的举措早在 2010 年就开始了。

;

;培养具有数字素养的一代的需要催生了一种更注重解决问题而不是记住事实的学习方法。学校也正在转向实时评估学生，而不仅仅是在紧张的考试条件下进行评估。这有助于改善学习反馈，并使教师能够提供更加个性化的学习计划。

;

;依靠同理心并更新教育，以保持人类相对于人工智能的优势

;

;该方法扩展到教师及其学生训练也。接触到全国各地的大量教师，尤其是农村地区的教师，可能是一项挑战。因此，引入了混合方法，包括通过 MuktoPaath 电子学习平台进行在线培训。

;

;通过实时仪表板监控培训传播情况，据观察，更多来自农村地区的教师完成了课程与城市地区相比，显示了技术在增加培训机会方面的力量。

;

;虽然孟加拉国在推动创新、混合学习方法方面处于领先地位，但它绝不是独一无二的。卢旺达在培训医护人员方面采取的混合方法促进了艾滋病毒/艾滋病护理。肯尼亚桥梁国际学院是采用混合学习方法的低成本私立学校，其学生在小学毕业考试中始终取得比全国平均水平高得多的成绩。混合式教育使用简单的数字工具来实现真正的社会流动性。

;

;要点很简单。在许多情况下，发展中国家别无选择，只能加速建立适合迅速到来的未来的教育体系。然而，这并不是因为对某一特定技术的痴迷。相反，它是通过一系列数字工具的低成本但高影响力的融合来实现的。

;

;在教育方面，没有灵丹妙药，即使对于人工智能也是如此。相反，像我国这样的国家正在关注那些已经被证明有效的解决方案，而不仅仅是承诺有效的解决方案。

;

;“他们袭击了住宅区的人道主义援助运送点，”马拉什科

;

;“四人当场死亡：分别为43岁、45岁和47岁的女性，以及一名47岁的男性。”

;

;乌克兰总检察长在一份声明中表示，袭击发生在当地时间前一天下午 1:20，造成 13 人受伤，除了遇难者之外。

;“我们相信，确保我们美国财政部长珍妮特·耶伦在上周对北京进行为期四天的访问之前表示：“高层之间有直接、明确的沟通渠道。”在首次访问中国时，她发誓尽管在一系列问题上存在分歧，但仍将帮助促进“稳定和建设性的关系”。

;

;耶伦明确表示，有“足够的空间”中美双边贸易以及具有全球意义的合作倡议，特别是针对气候变化的合作倡议。她表示，美国不会对中国采取零和博弈，而是致力于建立长期的贸易和投资关系。

;

;她的此行是在国务卿安东尼·布林肯访华后不久进行的。上个月对北京的访问强调了为稳定世界上最重要的双边关系而做出的不断努力。美国最高气候特使约翰·克里预计将于本月晚些时候访问，双方将探讨就共同关心的领域恢复双边对话。

;

;两个超级大国之间的长期缓和仍然是一项艰巨的任务，不过，由于针锋相对的制裁，美国经济战略的保护主义倾向日益明显，加上美国民众对中国的不信任感日益增强。

;

;公平地说，耶伦的访问对许多人来说是令人鼓舞的。尽管她对保护美国企业在华利益的必要性提出了挑衅的立场，但她还是与中国高层技术官僚进行了亲切的会面。其中包括会见李强总理，他谈到在经历了风雨飘摇的一年后，双边关系可能出现彩虹；以及会见中国经济沙皇和副总理何立峰，他以倡导对外国投资进一步开放而闻名。

;

;至关重要的是，耶伦强调美国将如何“寻求多元化，而不是与中国经济脱钩”，而是通过更加精准的“去风险”战略，专注于增强其供应链弹性和国家安全。她访问的最终目的是为两国关系奠定基础，阻止世界两个主要大国之间互动的危险螺旋式上升。

;

;尽管没有宣布重大外交突破，但她的访问为两国关系的进一步发展铺平了道路。美国总统乔·拜登和国家主席习近平举行双边峰会。这可能会在 9 月份在新德里举行的 20 国集团峰会或 11 月份在旧金山举行的亚太经合组织会议期间到来。

;

;即使在经济方面，也存在三个相互关联的因素，这些因素具有重要意义。两国领导人谈判长期缓和的能力受到限制。首先，美国已经转向“美国优先”的经济战略，这超出了特朗普政府的做法。耶伦在中国之行期间表示，“转向市场改革符合中国的利益”。

;

;与此同时，拜登政府对经济采取了更加保护主义的态度。早在 2020 年，未来的国家安全顾问、当时的拜登高级助手杰克·沙利文 (Jake Sullivan) 与人合着了一份报告，内容是美国需要如何采取积极的经济战略，既保护中产阶级，又确保国家保持同样的规模。在尖端行业中尽可能领先。

;

;抛售房产还是减少假期？中美中产阶级为艰难的2023年做准备

;

;自上台以来，拜登政府监督了三项关键立法的通过：两党基础设施​​法、芯片和科学法案以及降低通货膨胀法案法案，所有这些都动员了数万亿美元来增强美国的经济基础。在高度两极分化的政治环境中通过如此大规模的立法，证明了两党在美国应对中国挑战的必要性上达成了罕见的共识。

;

;除了加强其经济基础外，拜登政府还掀起了针对中国尖端产业的制裁浪潮。正如美国顶级智库战略与国际研究中心2022年的报告所言，我们所看到的无异于“美国积极扼杀中国科技产业大部分的新政策”。;

;这带来了第二个重大结构性挑战：公众对近期中美关系缓和的怀疑加深。看来美国政策精英对中国的看法得到了更广泛民众的认同。 3 月份公布的盖洛普民意调查发现，只有 15% 的美国受访者对中国的看法非常好或大多好，其中三分之二的受访者认为中国对美国的重大利益构成“严重威胁”。

;

;目前美国公众对中国的看法甚至低于冷战时期美国公众对苏联的看法。随着明年的大选，拜登政府将面临越来越大的压力，要求其对中国保持强硬立场。

;

;特朗普对中国的关税让美国付出了代价，但看起来可能会持续下去

;

;第三个，也许也是最关键的因素是美国经济战略对地缘政治战线的影响。北京一再坚称，恢复制度化的双边对话取决于美国取消制裁，这些制裁不仅针对中国的经济领军企业，还针对国防领导层。

;

;作为回应，拜登政府坚称外交应该没有先决条件。 ，几乎没有任何重大妥协的迹象。

;

;结果是，尽管两个超级大国继续加强在南海、台湾的海军存在，但仍然缺乏功能齐全的军事外交海峡和更广阔的西太平洋。简而言之，美国和中国领导人将不得不花费大量政治资本来实现近期迫切需要的外交突破。

;;

;

;

;中国居民消费价格指数 (CPI) 与a year earlier in June, down from 0.2 per cent growth in May.

;

;This was below the expected rise of 0.1 per cent, according to the Chinese financial data provider Wind, and was the lowest growth reading since February 2021.

;

;Beijing has set a CPI target of around 3 per cent growth for 2023.

;

;The decline in CPI inflation in June was mostly driven by non-food factors, as food price inflation has shown some signs of stabilising, analysts from Nomura said.

;

;Within the CPI, food prices increased by 2.3 per cent from a year earlier in June, compared with a rise of 1 per cent growth in May.

;

;Non-food prices, meanwhile, decreased last month, year on year, falling by 0.6 per cent after having remained flat in May.

;

;Prices for pork, a staple on Chinese dinner tables, decreased by 7.2 per cent in June compared with a year earlier, while fruit prices increased by 6.4 per cent and vegetable prices increased by 10.8 per cent.

;

;“Food-price inflation picked up, but this was more than offset by a fall in core inflation, from 0.6 per cent year on year to 0.4 per cent, and a decline in fuel price inflation to a 31-month low,” said economists at Capital Economics. “The former reflected slower price rises in travel and other in-person services, which reversed some of their earlier acceleration driven by [China's] reopening.”

;

;China's core consumer inflation rate, excluding the volatile prices of food and energy, increased by 0.4 per cent in June compared with a year earlier, down from 0.6 per cent growth in May.

;

;

;

;China's producer price index (PPI) fell by 5.4 per cent in June, year on year, down from a fall of 4.6 per cent in May, to its lowest point since December 2015 after remaining in deflationary territory for the ninth consecutive month.

;

;This was below expectations, with PPI having been expected to fall by 5 per cent last month, according to Wind.

;

;PPI reflects the prices that factories charge wholesalers for products.

;

;“The decline in PPI inflation in June was largely due to sequential price declines across a wide range of domestic raw materials, despite a lower base carried over from last year compared with May, as the initial effects from the Ukraine crisis started to moderate more meaningfully around this time last year,” said analysts at Nomura.

;

;Factory-gate prices also dropped by 0.8 per cent in month-on-month terms, with economists at Capital Economics pointing to the biggest declines coming in energy, metal and chemical prices, with consumer durable prices also retreating due to weak demand both within and outside China.

;

;

;

;Analysts at Nomura expect CPI inflation to slip further in July to minus 0.5 per cent, year on year, due partly to a high comparison base, even while taking into account a potential rise in service inflation as a result of the summer holiday season.

;

;They expect PPI inflation to rebound moderately to minus 4.5 per cent, year on year, in July, mostly due to a lower base.

;

;“The ultra-low inflation reading lends support to our view that the [People's Bank of China] is likely to implement two more rounds of policy rate cuts of 10 basis points each, and another 25-basis-point cut to the [reserve requirement ratio] over the rest of the year,” Nomura's analysts said.

;

;The central bank last cut the reserve requirement ratio – the amount that banks set aside for deposits – by 25 basis points in March.

;

;In June, the People's Bank of China cut the five-year loan prime rate (LPR) – which is a reference rate for mortgages – from 4.3 to 4.2 per cent. The one-year loan prime rate – the medium-term lending benchmark for corporate loans – was also cut from 3.65 to 3.55 per cent. Both key lending rates were last cut in August.

;

;“PPI deflation is likely to ease somewhat in the second half of the year, partly because infrastructure spending should put a floor under commodity prices. And core inflation could rise gradually, as a relatively tight labour market puts greater upward pressure on wages,” said economists at Capital Economics.

;

;“Fuel-price deflation, a key factor behind subdued headline inflation recently, will probably wane over the coming months. As such, we expect headline inflation to rise to around 1 per cent by the end of this year.

;

;“But this would still be soft and won't constrain the PBOC's ability to loosen policy further. That said, with credit demand weak, and the currency under pressure, we think the bulk of support will come through fiscal policy. We expect only another 10 basis points of policy rate cuts this year.”

; Tue, 11 Jul 2023 00:20:02 +0800 Hong Kong’s long-awaited plan to charge residents for waste delayed to next yearhttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3227225/hong-kongs-long-awaited-plan-charge-residents-waste-delayed-next-year?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.10 22:50;
;;

;A scheme to charge Hong Kong residents for each bag of rubbish they throw away has been pushed back to next year, delaying yet again a plan first floated nearly 20 years ago to transform the city's waste management.

;

;Charging would begin on April 1, instead of at the end of the year, the environment bureau told lawmakers on Monday, admitting more time was needed to work out the logistics of the scheme after waste collectors raised concerns over an expected surge in rubbish during the winter holidays.

;

;“Some sectors, such as the cleansing service providers, have been appealing for postponing the implementation, in view of the expected large quantity of waste that will be disposed of around Christmas and Chinese New Year, as well as the manpower shortage during Chinese New Year,” the bureau said in a paper submitted to the Legislative Council.

;

;“We therefore propose to implement municipal solid waste charging on 1 April 2024, which signifies a major milestone in waste management in Hong Kong.”

;

;An average three-person household is expected to pay HK$33 (US$4.20) a month for the government-approved bags, based on the assumption they produce 13 litres of rubbish daily.

;

;But a number of residents will be spared the expense for the first six months of the scheme. Authorities will hand out 20 bags, sized at 15 litres, to 1.05 million families living in public flats, rural areas and residential blocks with no owners' corporations.

;

;While the Housing Authority will help distribute them to public flat tenants, the bureau has yet to finalise with the Home Affairs Department how the other families covered by the free bag scheme will receive them.

;

;More refuse collection points would be established in rural areas, while large collection bins would be set up near the private housing blocks covered by the free bag scheme.

;

;Each bag will cost 11 HK cents, and after six months residents will face a HK$1,500 fine for using ones not designated by the government. Large waste that cannot be put into the bags will require a special label costing HK$11.

;

;“Frontline staff at relevant waste reception points will conduct visual screening as to whether the waste handed over to them has been properly wrapped in designated bags … and will reject any non-compliant waste,” the bureau said.

;

;14 years on, waste charging scheme to be mandatory in Hong Kong

;

;“For severe black spots with significant adverse impact to the community, ad hoc enforcement actions may be conducted even during the phasing-in period.”

;

;The government will also provide a HK$10 monthly subsidy to each recipient of Comprehensive Social Security Assistance or Old Age Living Allowance.

;

;Authorities are currently building a citywide network of supermarkets, convenience stores, pharmacies, homeware stores and online platforms to make it easier to buy the bags.

;

;The Environment and Ecology Bureau said authorities had received requests from 19 retail chains and online retailers to sell the bags and labels, covering 2,000 outlets and 11 digital platforms.

;

;In its Waste Blueprint for Hong Kong 2035, published in 2021, the government laid out plans to gradually reduce the per capita disposal rate by as much as 45 per cent and increase the recycling rate to about 55 per cent.

;

;Only about 30 per cent of the 4.15 million tonnes of municipal solid waste the city handled in 2021 was recycled, with the rest sent to landfills.

;

;Taipei has been charging for municipal waste since 2000, and Seoul since 1995. Both have seen at least 30 per cent reductions in waste.

;

;Hong Kong 'should delay waste-charging scheme until spring to prevent build-up'

;

;The idea of introducing a garbage levy in Hong Kong was first raised in 2004, with the government elaborating on how it would treat waste over the following decade.

;

;The administration of then chief executive Donald Tsang Yam-kuen proposed using economic incentives to encourage residents to recycle more and dispose of less.

;

;The idea of charging for disposal was entertained by the administrations that followed. A bill was drafted in 2018 and passed by lawmakers in 2021, but authorities were given 18 months to prepare for the switch.

;

;The scheme was to take effect at the end of this year, but last week, representatives of the waste-collecting sector warned the city would throw out more rubbish over the winter holiday than they could handle.

;

;Hong Kong 'should delay waste-charging scheme until spring to prevent build-up'

;

;The Environmental Services Contractors Alliance, which represents seven business groups and about 200 cleaning service companies, called the postponement good news for the industry.

;

;“It is ideal timing for the industry to learn a new waste management paradigm when the workforce is the most abundant,” alliance spokesman Raymond Yau Pui-lam said. “Garbage volume peaks from October to March, but reaches its trough between April and June.”

;

;He also called on authorities to hold more workshops so the industry could better understand the new system.

;

;But Beatrice Siu Wing-yin, a senior public affairs officer at environmental group Greeners Action, expressed disappointment over the delay.

;

;“We have been discussing the garbage levy for more than a decade,” she said. “The average daily waste disposal volume in Hong Kong has reached 11,300 tonnes. If authorities continue to drag on, the daily disposal amount will continue to pile up.”
